metadata.title: 5 Essential Resources to Jump-Start Your Machine Learning Adventures | by Ekin Tiu | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 5 Essential Resources to Jump-Start Your Machine Learning Adventures
metadata.description: That’s a great question. Often, it’s easy to get lost in the ocean of resources available on the shelf and on the internet. For all those curious beginners who are just looking for a place to start…

all_paragraphs: A frequent question I get from students interested in learning AI:
“Hey Ekin, what resources would you recommend for getting started in AI and ML?”
That’s a great question. Often, it’s easy to get lost in the ocean of resources available on the shelf and on the internet.

For all those curious beginners who are just looking for a place to start, here are the 5 essential resources that were instrumental in my own journey from zero to proficient (not a hero yet, but striving to get better everyday)!

As far as books for beginners goes, it doesn’t get better than this. In this free online book, Nielson carefully crafts a conceptually clear illustration of neural networks through both a principle-oriented approach and a hands-on approach.
Nielson writes with the beginner in mind, deliberately excluding unnecessary jargon and low-level slivers of information.

Although the ideas conveyed in this book are merely subsets of the broader field we call machine learning, they are unarguably critical ones that, when understood, break down the mental barriers to understanding ML and open wide the doors of comprehension.

For anyone even remotely interested in artificial intelligence, Siraj is your guy. Replete with relevant humor and high-level visuals, Siraj’s videos break down intricate AI concepts in an engaging, yet didactic manner.
His videos cover almost every notable topic in AI. He’s made videos ranging from a 5 minute TensorFlow tutorial to a series on the Math behind AI.
Kaggle, advertised as “Your Home for Data Science”, is the perfect resource to grow as a data scientist as it allows you to practically apply machine learning concepts.
Kaggle itself is equipped with a vast range of resources: hands-on tutorials, introductory competitions, exploratory kernels (more on this in a second), and more.
Moreover, Kaggle is a community, swarming with highly enthusiastic data scientists who are 100% willing to help.
(A Kaggle Kernel is a free development environment in the browser. More on Kaggle Kernels here:)

If you’re reading this article, then it is very likely that you understand the value of medium articles. Towards Data Science on Medium is a broad compendium of concise, illuminating articles passionately written by data science enthusiasts.
If you don’t understand a complicated concept, it may help to search that concept on TDS.
by Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, and Aaron Courville

Though (very) math-intensive, this book solidified my foundation. It gave me the ability to understand the more rigorous concepts in the field. In a way, it prepared me for the rigors of academic literature (i.e. research papers).

The book is intended to be a deep learning textbook. So yes, as we would expect, it has the properties of a standard textbook: jargon and precise definitions. What it lacks in readability, it more than compensates in quality.
It does an excellent job of explaining ML and DL concepts formally, thereby filling in the gaps left by simpler resources.
You’ve just taken the first step to getting started: figuring out where to get started.
Machine learning is an extensive field, and the resources listed above by no means cover every detail.
Remember to use these resources as launching pads to gradually strengthen your foundation in both machine learning and the popular subset, deep learning.
Now that you know where to start, channel your enthusiasm and give it all you’ve got!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
CS @ Stanford University | Stanford ML Group
